So yeah ended up going to the MtvU campus invasion tour yesterday. Suffice it to say it was freakin' amazing. Got Ronnie Day to sign my copy of The Album, which basically made the whole day worth it. Augustana was surprisingly awesome live, given how mellow their album is. Got some free stuff, and just generally had some awesome time. Rather than do some half-assed disorganized account, I will present to you the following:

High Points of the Day
-Monster brought out one of its trucks to give away free Monster to everyone waiting in the long-ass line on Columbus Blvd. to get into the show. If you've never had Monster before, be aware it should be had sparingly, especially if you're me.
-Meeting and getting an auotgraph from Ronnie Day before anyone realized who he was
-Being about 4 rows away from 2 of the 3 opening acts (Kidz in the Hall and K-OS...Kenna was wrapping up by the time I got there)
-The hut where they were giving away all kinds of free stuff and had awesome games when you didn't feel like hearing the music
-Very nearly catching some of the swag the Mtv emcee was throwing off the stage.
-Sunshowers. When the rain comes, all the silly MTV kids run for the hut, so I can take their spot near the stage.
-The awesome dude that conned a roadie into giving him one of K-OS's drumsticks
-Augustana rocks surprisingly hard for being a piano-based band
-Augustana's extra 3-minute jam session near the end of "Boston"
-Being about 15 feet from Travis (guy from Gym Class Heroes) and not realizing it
-GCH's tirade about fans who come up to him and start rapping ("After a show, I'm all tired and sweaty, and all I really wanna do is get into my pajamas, get into bed and watch some Grey's Anatomy!"
-Front row, stage left for Ronnie Day
-Ronnie Day going unplugged after his guitar battery dies (more on that later)
-Working my way up to within 4 rows of the stage (stage right side) in time for Dashboard's set and never being more than 8 rows away from the stage.
-Dashboard Confessional still playing old-school songs and letting the crowd sing along
-DC's tribute to VA Tech students, hence the quote above and a cover of "Teenage Dirtbag"
-Closing out the show with "Hands Down" + jam session
-All of the above and still being home before midnight

Not-So Good Parts
-In my rush to get out in time to catch the train, I forgot to grab my camera.
-Walking from Market St. to the Festival Pier. Never realized how long that walk was.
-The dumbasses in front of me in line to get into the show
-The Guitar Hero tourney in the hut didn't have any songs unlocked and you couldn't hear the game music for crap...poor execution...
-The MTV emcee was kind of a jerk. For a minute I thought he was Jay-Z, but I doubt Jay-Z would blast "This Is Why I'm Hot" so shamelessly.
-Schools that had flags or banners represented at the show: Penn State, UPenn, St. Joe's, Temple, Albright, one or two others. Despite having a surprising number of students there, Arcadia gets snubbed.
-The dumb chain-smoking bitches during Augustana's set that kept yelling about how dumb and stupid they were and how they were just there for Gym Class Heroes. Look, if you don't like the band that's playing, quit ruining it for the rest of us and leave till your act comes on!
-The long-as-hell line to get an autograph from Augustana
-OK, so after Ronnie Day's guitar battery dies, he gets down on the ground and we all form a campfire circle around him while he plays (keep in mind he's on the 2nd stage and on the mainstage the emcee is giving away stuff and whatnot). We get through the first chorus of "Outside" when suddenly our singing is drowned out by none other than "This Is Why I'm Hot". We all proceed to boo and ultimately Ronnie's set is cut tragically short. Fuck You MTV!!!
-Food at the Pier is mad expensive. A 20 oz. Powerade set me back 3 bucks!
-Stupid MTV kids that bitch about wanting to see Dashboard so much, but by the time he starts playing they stand there like zombies with no expressions on their face. And during the older tracks, they're noticably not singing along. Coincidence? I think not!
-The dumbass who screamed "JUST PLAY!!" when Chris Carabba asked for a moment of silence for VA Tech. I hope this guy got curbstomped.

With the xanga all but defunct, this and the myspace blog are gonna start getting most of the entries these days. I'm looking for a good place to start an entirely music-oriented blog. Last.fm is OK, but its too low profile and I don't see the kind of thing I'm looking for in it. Any suggestions on a new spot are welcome.

While I'm thinking about it, new entry on the Last.fm blog, not attached to that project I mentioned last time. Check it out if you feel like it. Meantime, some musings on what I'm excited for in 2007.

Fall Out Boy - The only band to have its album complete and ready to release so far, excitement is already builiding for the February 6th release of Infinity on High. The first single "This Ain't A Scene, It's An Arms Race" has been climbing radio charts for a few weeks now, and early listens to the album suggest an angrier FOB. Frontman Pete Wentz already admitted that "This Ain't A Scene..." was written in response to criticism he and his band received since exploding onto the scene in 2005. Perhaps all the touring and exposure has left FOB a bit jaded? If the result sounds like the first single, then more, please!

Jimmy Eat World - The Tempe, AZ band has already announced that they will be rereleasing their first two LPs, Clarity and Static Prevails on May 15th with bonus tracks and demos. In addition, they are in the studio finishing up the new yet-to-be-titled album, hoping for an early summer release. In my exploration of oldschool emo I tried out a few tracks from the early albums and I gotta say, I was really impressed. Reports from the JEW camp call the new album 'eclectic', containing a little bit of everything fans have come to expect and then some. Look for a tour to accompany the new album.

Omnisoul - Odds are you've never heard of this Wilmington, DE based band. There only two tracks come from the soundtracks to Fantastic 4 and Madden 2007. From the former, "Waiting (Save Your Life)" is a pretty nice rock ballad, the kind of thing you might expect from The All-American Rejects. "Not Giving Up" from the Madden 07 soundtrack, is exactly what you'd expect from such a playlist; a bouncy, upbeat locker room anthem with the slightest twinge of an angry Maroon 5. The band signed to Wind-Up Records (also home to Evanescence, Alter Bridge, and the now-defunct Creed) early in 2005, and after endless touring, the band should have its first full-length release out sometime this year. The band has been compared to Howie Day, Coldplay and John Mayer. If you're a fan of any of them, keep your ears peeled.

Linkin Park - The rap-rock quintet went into the studio in November to begin work on their fourth studio album with nearly 120 tracks to work from. The band expects to cull the best 18 tracks into a full-length album. According to a story in a November issue of Rolling Stone, producer Rick Rubin has encouraged the band to look beyond the formulaic rap/scream vocals and crunching guitars that led to the success of their previous albums. The band is aiming for a March release, perhaps aiming to compete with Guns N Roses (more on them later) and beat Metallica to the CD racks. Say what you will about Reanimation, but I think Linkin Park has yet to release a truly unimpressive record, and if they really do back away from the rap-metal influence, they could have something really big on their hands.

Disturbed - Still riding the success of 2005's Ten Thousand Fists, its unlikely that Disturbed is in any rush to release new material. But with System Of A Down and Staind each taking a hiatus and Ozzy unlikely to appear on this summer's Ozzfest, look for Disturbed to rule the hard rock/metal world for awhile. You might see Disturbed and (Mudvayne/Pantera project) Hellyeah! to be a big draw in time for the summer tour craze. Ever since Believe I thought Disturbed was wildly underrated and lost in SoaD's shadow. It took till this past Ozzfest for me to be proven right, now let's see how it pans out from here.

So for the past week every news station in America has been doing pretty much nonstop coverage leading up to the Da Vinci Code movie. Personally I could not be less interested. I've not yet read the book and know very little about the controversy surrounding it. For added fun I don't plan on seeing the movie, especially given the less-than-stellar reviews tied to it. I don't see why its all causing such a huge stink.

What I'm fascinated, and slightly confused by, is the amount of uproar a piece of entertainment has generated. I mean, a friggin' movie is causing riots, debates, and creating such backlash from the largest established relgion in the world. Has any other film, book, or event in recent history created a worldwide response the way The Da Vinci Code has? I get that people are somewhat offended by the religious implications, but I think many people are simultaneously reminding others of something, while forgetting that same thing; it's a work of FICTION. Maybe Dan Brown did some research prior to writing the book, as many authors do, but at the same time the guy's allowed to put what he wants in his book. Much in the same way Oliver Stone had his implications on JFK's death, Dan Brown can create any interpretations on the life of Christ he pleases. And last I checked, Brown hasn't said he believes in what he wrote, thus furthering the 'work of fiction' defense. Maybe if people stopped getting so perturbed when their "infallible" religion is seen in a way that might not be completely glorifying and accepted alternate possibilities, we'd be able to handle things like this better.

That's it; I'm making everyone in Americaaround the world see Dogma.

Oh, and another thing; if a piece of literature or film considered fiction can question the faith of so many people, doesn't that say something about how fickle those people are, and how easily broken their faith is? Shouldn't the church be doing more to solidify people's faith rather than going out bashing and trying to bring down The Da Vinci Code? I think there needs to be a shift in priorities.

I mean, religion and entertainment have been intertwined for decades; Jesus Christ Superstar, The Last Temptation of Christ, and Kingdom of Heaven to name a few. It's just another interpretation. If people are going to get upset over portrayals of Jesus, shouldn't those same people be upset with the Heaven/Hell/God imagery in Lost? But yet other countries think its funny as hell when we take shots at Mohammed or some other religion, and then we tell them to chill out when they get offended and stuff. Kinda ironic too how 2 years ago we all used film to restore our faith thanks to The Passion of the Christ, and now we're using the same media to bring it down with Da Vinci Code.

So I guess my point is that entertainment should be just that; it shouldn't build or destroy beliefs, cause riots, or incite revolutions. It should get people thinking, but it's not meant to cause the kind of response this has.

And I'm serious. Everyone around the world should see Dogma if they're so up in arms about The Da Vinci Code.
